SafetyInspectionBy: Iowa Department of Agriculture & Land Stewardship

_accidents.CI_OtherType: Prior to this event,  consideration was being given to ceasingNH3 operations at this location.   After the incident, the facility was emptied, rmoved and operations conducted at an alternate location.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
West Central Cooperative - Halbur



FACILITY POLICY:

West Central Cooperative is committed to the prevention of any accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia.  Bi-annual inspections and maintenance are required on all storage facilities, loading and unloading facilities, application equipment and portable tanks.  All employees who handle anhydrous ammonia are required to attend bi-annual training which emphas the properties of anhydrous ammonia, the affects of anhydrous ammonia on the human body, operating procedures, emergency procedures, and emergency first aid.  PPE, including gloves, goggles, hard hats, emergency water, and sturdy work cloths & shoes are required whenever handling anhydrous ammonia.  If an accidental release should occur, this facility is prepared to work with local fire departments, LEPCA?s, law enforcement, or other authorities to mitigate the impact of the release to people and the environment.  



FACILITY INFORMATION:

The primary activity at this facility is the storage and blending of fertilizers for sale to farmer customers.  Anhydrous ammonia is received by truck and kept in (a) storage tank(s) until distributed to customers in mobile nurse tanks for use as a nitrogen fertilizer.  The storage tank(s), several anhydrous ammonia nurse tanks, risers for filling the nurse tanks, pumps and controls, lighting and safety equipment are all part of the facilities anhydrous ammonia operation.  The facility is staffed during seasonal operating hours, and is secured when not in operation.  Security includes area lighting, closing and locking the main valve (belly valve) from the storage tank(s), locking out power to pumps, closing fill hose end valves and locking them in a box that prevents unauthorized access to them, locking nurse tank unloading valves, and walk-thru inspections.



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM:

This facility has implemented the provisions of A?Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia, K-6

1-1A? published by the American National Standards Institute, Inc., the standards of the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) 29 CFR 1910.111 A?Storage and Handling of Anhydrous AmmoniaA?, and the Iowa Fertilize Law.  Annual inspections by Iowa Department of Agriculture and Land Stewardship (IDALS) are made on facilities and portable nurse tanks.  Frequent site inspections are made by management and safety consultants.  Equipment  inspections, maintenance and employee training are conducted prior to every application season.



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY:

There was am accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia on May 24, 2014.  It did not cause any death, injuries at the facility or off site.  There were also no  evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage off site.  There was contamination to the soil in the area and to water in nearby Brushy Creek.  The Halbur Fire Department responded to the incident to help control and stop the release.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM:

This facility has a written emergency action plan, in accordance with OSHA standard 29 CFR 1910.38.  The facility has also provided state and local authorities the emergency planning and community right-to-know information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA), and has coordinated with local emergency responders.  



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY:

Safety improvement is an on-going process at this facility.  Periodic evaluations are performed to asses the maintenance of safe conditions.  There are no additional specific anhydrous ammonia safety recommendations for implantation at this time.

for implementation at this time.
